awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Summer Research Program on Mind and Brain
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Colorado State University was to stimulate student interest in the science of mind and brain, and prepare and enhance students' prospects for pursuing graduate study and careers in the mind/brain sciences. We were particularly interested in providing this opportunity to students from historically underrepresented populations, as well as students from institutions that lack comparable research opportunities and lack access to state-of-the-art research facilities and equipment. During the summers of 2006-2012, we brought a total of 73 students to Colorado State University for a nine-week summer research program, with over 80% of them from primarily undergraduate institutions, over 70% of them women, and over 60% from underrepresented populations. These students, under the mentorship of a faculty member, attained specialized training and research experience in a topic area withn the field of perception, cognition, perceptual neuroscience, or cognitive neuroscience. With the guidance of the faculty mentor, each student developed, administered, and analyzed her or his own experiment. In addition, they (a) attended a weekly research seminar in which participating faculty presented and led discussion of the methods, issues, and findings from their own area of expertise; (b) attended a weekly seminar that covered topics pertaining to research ethics and professional development; (c) participated in workshops on the use of our state-of the-art equipment (driving simulator, EEG equipment, eyetracker, etc.); (d) participated in additional workshops on experiment construction and data analysis using E-Prime and SPSS; (e) went on a site visit to the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center to learn about fMRI and MEG methods; and (f) optionally completed a sophomore-level course entitled Mind, Brain, & Behavior. As a capstone experience, students presented their work in poster format during a research symposium held at the end of the nine-week session. 


This REU Site was exceptionally well-received by student participants. When asked to rate whether their overall experience was a positive one, the average student rating was 4.9 out of 5 (with 5=strongly agree) and when asked whether they'd recommend the program to other students, the average rating was also 4.9 out of 5. The intellectual impact was quite significant. Students not only gained knowledge in the particular topic area in which they conducted research, but also considerable knowledge and experience pertaining to experimental design, statistical methods, ethics, and the written and oral communication of research findings. In addition, they acquired skills in using various research tools and equipment. Reflecting this, when asked to rate whether the program was helpful in understanding and appreciating research on the mind and brain, the average student rating was 4.9 out of 5, and when asked to rate whether the program was helpful in acquiring research and laboratory skills, the average rating was 4.8. It is also noteworthy that the research conducted by participants has contributed in a meaningful way to our general knowledge about the mind and brain. Student research projects have resulted in several peer-reviewed journal articles and over 50 presentations at regional and national professional conferences, with the student participants as co-authors. The program also fostered the development of the next generation of scientists studying the mind and brain. Students reported that the program was quite useful in helping them decide whether they wished to an advanced degree and career in science, and that the program gave them the confidence and initial set of skills to do so. When asked to rate whether the program was helpful to them in considering whether or not to go to graduate or medical school, the average rat...
